Recent advances in the Langlands Program

Edward Frenkel Department of Mathematics, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA
(Date:: December 2002, revised in September 2003. Notes for the lecture at the ‚ÄúCurrent Events‚Äù special session of the AMS meeting in Baltimore, January 17, 2003.)

1. Introduction

1.1.

The Langlands Program has emerged in the late 60‚Äôs in the form of a series of far-reaching conjectures tying together seemingly unrelated objects in number theory, algebraic geometry, and the theory of automorphic forms [L1]. To motivate it, recall the classical Kronecker-Weber theorem which describes the maximal abelian extension ‚Ñöab of the field ‚Ñö of rational numbers (i.e., the maximal extension of ‚Ñö whose Galois group is abelian). This theorem states that ‚Ñöab is obtained by adjoining to ‚Ñö all roots of unity; in other words, ‚Ñöab is the union of all cyclotomic fields ‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N) obtained by adjoining to ‚Ñö a primitive Nth root of unity Œ∂N.

The Galois group Gal‚Å°(‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N)/‚Ñö) of automorphisms of ‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N) preserving ‚Ñö‚äÇ‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N) is isomorphic to the group (‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó of units of the ring ‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§. Indeed, each element m‚àà(‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó, viewed as an integer relatively prime to N, gives rise to an automorphism of ‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N) which sends Œ∂N to Œ∂Nm. Therefore we obtain that the Galois group Gal‚Å°(‚Ñöab/‚Ñö), or, equivalently, the maximal abelian quotient of Gal‚Å°(‚Ñö¬Ø/‚Ñö), where ‚Ñö is an algebraic closure of ‚Ñö, is isomorphic to the projective limit of the groups (‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó with respect to the system of surjections (‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó‚Üí(‚Ñ§/M‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó for M dividing N. This projective limit is nothing but the direct product of the multiplicative groups of the rings of p‚Äìadic integers, ‚Ñ§p√ó, where p runs over the set of all primes. Thus, we obtain that

Gal‚Å°(‚Ñöab/‚Ñö)‚âÉ‚àèp‚Ñ§p√ó.

The abelian class field theory gives a similar description for the maximal abelian quotient Gal‚Å°(Fab/F) of the Galois group Gal‚Å°(F¬Ø/F), where F is an arbitrary global field, i.e., a finite extension of ‚Ñö (number field), or the field of rational functions on a smooth projective curve defined over a finite field (function field). Namely, Gal‚Å°(Fab/F) is almost isomorphic to the quotient F√ó\ùî∏F√ó, where ùî∏F is the ring of ad√®les of F, a subring in the direct product of all completions of F (see Section¬†2). Here we use the word ‚Äúalmost‚Äù because we need to take the group of components of this quotient if F is a number field, or its profinite completion if F is a function field.

When F=‚Ñö the ring ùî∏‚Ñö is a subring of the direct product of the fields ‚Ñöp of p‚Äìadic numbers and the field ‚Ñù of real numbers, and the quotient F√ó\ùî∏F√ó is isomorphic to ‚Ñù>0√ó‚àèp‚Ñ§p√ó. Hence the group of its components is ‚àèp‚Ñ§p√ó, in agreement with the Kronecker-Weber theorem.

One can obtain complete information about the maximal abelian quotient of a group by considering its one-dimensional representations. The above statement of the abelian class field theory may then be reformulated as saying that one-dimensional representations of Gal‚Å°(F¬Ø/F) are essentially in bijection with one-dimensional representations of the abelian group ùî∏F√ó=G‚Å¢L1‚Å¢(ùî∏F) which occur in the space of functions on F√ó\ùî∏F√ó=G‚Å¢L1‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢L1‚Å¢(ùî∏F). A marvelous insight of Robert Langlands was to conjecture that there exists a similar description of n‚Äìdimensional representations of Gal‚Å°(F¬Ø/F). Namely, he proposed that those may be related to irreducible representations of the group G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏F) which are automorphic, that is those occurring in the space of functions on the quotient G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏F). This relation is now called the Langlands correspondence.

1.2.

At this point one might ask a legitimate question: why is it important to know what the n‚Äìdimensional representations of the Galois group look like, and why is it useful to relate them to things like automorphic representations? There are indeed many reasons for that. First of all, it should be remarked that according to the Tannakian phylosophy, one can reconstruct a group from the category of its finite-dimensional representations, equipped with the structure of the tensor product. Therefore looking at n‚Äìdimensional representations of the Galois group is a natural step towards understanding its structure. But even more importantly, one finds many interesting representations of Galois groups in ‚Äúnature‚Äù. For example, the group Gal‚Å°(‚Ñö¬Ø/‚Ñö) will act on the geometric invariants (such as the √©tale cohomologies) of an algebraic variety defined over ‚Ñö. Thus, if we take an elliptic curve E over ‚Ñö, then we will obtain a two-dimensional Galois representation on its first √©tale cohomology. This representation contains a lot of important information about the curve E, such as the number of points of E over ‚Ñ§/p‚Å¢‚Ñ§ for various primes p.

The point is that the Langlands correspondence is supposed to relate n‚Äìdimensional Galois representations to automorphic representations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏F) in such a way that the data on the Galois side, such as the number of points of E‚Å¢(‚Ñ§/p‚Å¢‚Ñ§), are translated into something more tractable on the automorphic side, such as the coefficients in the q‚Äìexpansion of the modular forms that encapsulate automorphic representations of G‚Å¢L2‚Å¢(ùî∏‚Ñö).

More precisely, one asks that under the Langlands correspondence certain natural invariants attached to the Galois representations and to the automorphic representations be matched. These invariants are the Frobenius conjugacy classes on the Galois side and the Hecke eigenvalues on the automorphic side. Let us review them briefly. To an n‚Äìdimensional representation œÉ of Gal‚Å°(F¬Ø/F) that is almost everywhere unramified one attaches a collection of conjugacy classes in the group G‚Å¢Ln for all but finitely many points x of the curve X if F=ùîΩq‚Å¢(X) (or primes of the ring of integers of F if F is a number field). These are the images of the Frobenius elements in Gal‚Å°(F¬Ø/F) (see Section¬†2.1). The eigenvalues of these conjugacy classes are then represented by unordered n‚Äìtuples of numbers (z1‚Å¢(œÉx),‚Ä¶,zn‚Å¢(œÉx)). On the other hand, to an automorphic representation œÄ of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) one attaches a collection of eigenvalues of the so-called Hecke operators (see Section¬†2.2), which may also be encoded by unordered collections of n‚Äìtuples of numbers (z1‚Å¢(œÄx),‚Ä¶,zn‚Å¢(œÄx)) for all but finitely many x‚ààX. If under the Langlands correspondence we have

œÄ‚ü∑œÉ,

then we should have

(1.1) (z1‚Å¢(œÄx),‚Ä¶,zn‚Å¢(œÄx))=(z1‚Å¢(œÉx),‚Ä¶,zn‚Å¢(œÉx))

for all but finitely many x‚ààX (up to permutation).

The Frobenius eigenvalues and the Hecke eigenvalues may be converted into analytic objects called the L‚Äìfunctions. Then the matching of these eigenvalues becomes the statement that the L‚Äìfunctions corresponding to œÄ and œÉ are equal.

It is instructive to consider what this matching means in the simplest example when F=‚Ñö and n=1. In this case the Langlands correspondence comes from the isomorphism between the abelian quotient of the Galois group Gal‚Å°(‚Ñöab/‚Ñö) and the group of components of ‚Ñö√ó\ùî∏‚Ñö√ó. The matching condition (1.1) then means that the Frobenius element Frp corresponding to the prime p‚àà‚Ñ§ in Gal‚Å°(‚Ñöab/‚Ñö) (more precisely, of its quotient unramified at p) goes under this isomorphism to the image of the ad√®le (1,‚Ä¶,1,p,1,‚Ä¶), with p being in the factor ‚Ñöp√ó, in the group of components of ‚Ñö√ó\ùî∏‚Ñö√ó.

Let us represent the latter group as lim‚üµ‚Å¢(‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó, where (‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó is considered as the Galois group Gal‚Å°(‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N)/‚Ñö) of the cyclotomic field ‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N). Then the above statement translates into the statement as to what is the image of the Frobenius conjugacy class Frp in Gal‚Å°(‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N)/‚Ñö)=(‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó. It says that this image is equal to p‚Å¢mod‚Å°N; note that this makes sense only if p does not divide N, which is precisely the condition that p is unramified in ‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N). Since the Frobenius element Frp comes from the automorphism y‚Ü¶yp of the finite field ùîΩp, it is not surprising that it corresponds to the automorphism of ‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N) sending Œ∂N to Œ∂Np.

Thus, we find that the order of Frp in Gal‚Å°(‚Ñö‚Å¢(Œ∂N)/‚Ñö) is equal to the order of p in (‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó. Therefore we may figure out how p splits in the ring ‚Ñ§‚Å¢[Œ∂N]. If the order of Frp is equal to d and (p)=ùí´1‚Å¢‚Ä¶‚Å¢ùí´r, where the ùí´i‚Äôs are prime ideals in ‚Ñ§‚Å¢[Œ∂N], then the residue field of each of the ùí´i‚Äôs should be an extension of ùîΩp of degree d, and therefore r=œÜ‚Å¢(N)/d, where œÜ‚Å¢(N)=|(‚Ñ§/N‚Å¢‚Ñ§)√ó|. So we obtain an application of the matching (1.1) in the case n=1 to the problem of the splitting of primes. For instance, if N=4 we obtain that p splits in ‚Ñ§‚Å¢[i], i.e., p may be represented as a sum of two squares of integers,

p=(a+b‚Å¢i)‚Å¢(a-b‚Å¢i)=a2+b2,

if and only if p‚â°1‚Å¢mod‚Å°4, which is the statement of one of Fermat‚Äôs theorems (see [Ge] for more details).

Likewise, in the case of two-dimensional Galois representations œÉ arising from the first √©tale cohomology of an elliptic curve E over ‚Ñ§, the eigenvalues of Frp (which are well-defined for all p‚Äôs that do not divide the conductor of E) contain information about the number of points of E over ‚Ñ§/p‚Å¢‚Ñ§. Suppose now that œÄ is an automorphic representation of G‚Å¢L2‚Å¢(ùî∏) attached to œÉ via the Langlands correspondence. One assigns to œÄ in a natural way a modular form on the upper-half plane (see, e.g., [Ge, Mu]). Then the matching condition (1.1) relates the numbers of points of E‚Å¢(‚Ñ§/p‚Å¢‚Ñ§) to the coefficients in the q‚Äìexpansion of this modular form. The existence of œÄ (and hence of the corresponding modular form) now becomes the statement of the Taniyama-Shimura (or Taniyama-Shimura-Weil) conjecture that has recenty been proved by A. Wiles and others (it implies the Fermat‚Äôs last theorem). One obtains similar statements by analyzing from the point of view of the Langlands philosophy the Galois representations coming from other algebraic varieties, or more general motives.

1.3.

While in the number field case the Langlands correspondence has been established only in special cases such as the one expressed by the Taniyama-Shimura conjecture, in the function field case the Langlands conjecture is now a theorem. It has been proved in the 80‚Äôs by V. Drinfeld in the case when n=2 and recently by L. Lafforgue for an arbitrary n in a monumental effort for which both of them have been awarded the Fields Medals.

In these notes we will focus on the Langlands correspondence in the function field case. We will start by giving a precise formulation of the Langlands conjecture in this case (see Section¬†2). Then in Section¬†3 we will describe some of the ideas involved in the proof of this conjecture given by Drinfeld and Lafforgue.

After that we will discuss in Section¬†4 the geometric Langlands correspondence. This is a geometric version of the Langlands conjecture (available only in the function field case). It comes from the observation that n‚Äìdimensional representations of Gal‚Å°(F¬Ø/F), where F=ùîΩq‚Å¢(X), may be viewed geometrically as rank n local systems on X. Such objects make sense both when X is a curve over a finite field and over ‚ÑÇ. Thus, we may transport the objects on the Galois side of the Langlands correspondence to the realm of complex algebraic geometry.

It turns out that one may replace the automorphic repsentations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) by geometric objects as well. Those are the Hecke eigensheaves, which are certain sheaves on the moduli space of rank n bundles on the curve. The geometric Langlands conjecture states, roughly, that to any rank n local system E on X one may associate a Hecke eigensheaf whose ‚Äúeigenvalues‚Äù are expressed in terms of E. The advantage of this formulation is that it makes sense for curves defined not only over finite fields, but also over the field of complex numbers. Hence one can use the machinery of complex algebraic geometry to gain new insights into the nature of the Langlands correspondence. For example, for n=1 the geometric Langlands conjecture states that to each rank one local system E on X one can associate a Hecke eigensheaf on the Jacobean variety of X. It turns out that when X is a curve over ‚ÑÇ this correspondence is best understood in the framework of the Fourier-Mukai transform (see Section¬†6.2).

The geometric Langlands conjecture for G‚Å¢Ln has recently been proved in [FGV, Ga] following earlier works of P. Deligne, V. Drinfeld [Dr4] and G. Laumon [La2, La3]. In Section¬†4 we will give an overview of this proof.

Then in Section¬†5 we will discuss how to formulate the Langlands correspondence for an arbitrary reductive group G instead of G‚Å¢Ln, both in the classical and the geometric settings. This is where one of the most beautiful and mysterious concepts, that of the Langlands dual group, enters the subject. Finally, we will describe in Section¬†6 the work [BD] of A. Beilinson and V. Drinfeld in which part of this conjecture has been proved for an arbitrary semisimple Lie group G over ‚ÑÇ. Their proof uses the geometry of moduli spaces of bundles on curves as well as representation theory of affine Kac-Moody algebras.

In the last thirty years the subject of the Langlands correspondence has evolved into a vast and multifaceted field. In a short review it is impossible to even glance over its main ideas and trends. In particular, we will not mention such remarkable recent achievements as the proof of the local Langlands conjectures for G‚Å¢Ln, both in the function field and number field settings, given in [LSR] and [HT, He], respectively (in that regard we refer the reader to Carayol‚Äôs talk at S√©minaire Bourbaki [C]).

A number of wonderful reviews of the Langlands Program are available at present, and I would like to mention some of them. The papers [A1, A2, Ge, Kn, Mu] contain general overviews of the Langlands Program which are informative and fun to read. The reports [Kaz] and [HK] give a clear and concise review of the work of Drinfeld in the case of G‚Å¢L2. For excellent expositions of Lafforgue‚Äôs work and the geometric Langlands correspondence we refer the reader to Laumon‚Äôs talks at S√©minaire Bourbaki, [La5] and [La6], respectively. Finally, the recent article [L2] offers a unique perspective on the field by its Creator ‚Äúthirty years later‚Äù.

2. The statement of the Langlands conjecture in the function field case

Let X be a smooth projective curve over a finite field k=ùîΩq with q elements. We will denote by X¬Ø the corresponding curve over the algebraic closure ùîΩ¬Øq of ùîΩq, X¬Ø=X‚Å¢√óSpec‚Å°ùîΩq‚Å¢Spec‚Å°ùîΩ¬Øq. We will assume that X¬Ø is connected. Let F=ùîΩq‚Å¢(X) be the field of rational functions on X, and fix its separable closure F¬Ø. We denote by GF the Galois group of F, i.e., the group of automorphisms of F¬Ø preserving F.

For any closed point x of X, we denote by Fx the completion of F at x and by ùí™x its ring of integers. If we pick a rational function tx on X which vanishes at x to order one, then we obtain isomorphisms Fx‚âÉkx‚Å¢((tx)) and ùí™x‚âÉkx‚Å¢[[tx]], where kx is the residue field of x (the quotient of the local ring ùí™x by its maximal ideal); this field is a finite extension of the base field k and hence is isomorphic to ùîΩqx, where qx=qdeg‚Å°x. The ring ùî∏=ùî∏F of ad√®les of F is by definition the restricted product of the fields Fx, where x runs over the set |X| of all closed points of X. The word ‚Äúrestricted‚Äù means that we consider only the collections (fx)x‚àà|X| of elements of Fx in which fx‚ààùí™x for all but finitely many x. The ring ùî∏ contains the field F, which is embedded into ùî∏ diagonally, by taking the expansions of rational functions on X at all points.

Roughly speaking, the Langlands conjecture states that there is a bijection between the set of equivalence classes of n‚Äìdimensional representations of GF and the set of equivalence classes of irreducible automorphic representations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏), i.e., those which may be realized in a certain space of functions on the quotient G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). In order to make a precise formulation of the conjecture, we need to explain what all of this means. We will also restrict ourselves to irreducible n‚Äìdimensional representations of GF. Those will correspond to the so-called cuspidal representations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). In addition, using the abelian class field theory, we can without loss of generality consider only those representations of GF, whose determinant has finite order, and those representations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) whose central character has finite order (a general representation may be obtained by tensoring a representation of this type with a one-dimensional representation). Let us now give the precise definitions.

2.1. Galois representations

Consider the Galois group GF. It is instructive to think of it as a kind of fundamental group of X. Indeed, if Y‚ÜíX is a covering of X, then the field k‚Å¢(Y) of rational functions on Y is an extension of the field F=k‚Å¢(X) of rational functions on X, and the Galois group Gal‚Å°(k‚Å¢(Y)/k‚Å¢(X)) may be viewed as the group of ‚Äúdeck transformations‚Äù of the cover. If our cover is unramified, then this group may be identified with a quotient of the fundamental group of X. Otherwise, this group is isomorphic to a quotient of the fundamental group of X without the ramification points. The Galois group GF itself may be viewed as the group of ‚Äúdeck transformations‚Äù of the maximal (ramified) cover of X.

Let us pick a point x¬Ø of this cover lying over a fixed point x‚àà|X|. The subgroup of GF preserving x¬Ø is called the decomposition group. If we make a different choice of x¬Ø, it gets conjugated in GF. Therefore we obtain a subgroup of GF defined up to conjugation. We denote it by Dx. This group is in fact isomorphic to the Galois group Gal‚Å°(F¬Øx/Fx), and we have a natural homomorphism Dx‚ÜíGal‚Å°(k¬Øx/kx), whose kernel is called the inertia subgroup and is denoted by Ix. The Galois group Gal‚Å°(k¬Øx/kx) has a very simple description: it contains the (geometric) Frobenius element Frx, which is defined to be the inverse of the automorphism y‚Ü¶yqx of k¬Øx=ùîΩ¬Øqx, and Gal‚Å°(k¬Øx/kx) is equal to the profinite completion of the group ‚Ñ§ generated by this element.

A homomorphism œÉ from GF to another group H is called unramified at x, if Ix lies in the kernel of œÉ (this condition is independent of the choice of x¬Ø). In this case Frx gives rise to a well-defined conjugacy class in H, denoted by œÉ‚Å¢(Frx).

The group GF is a profinite group, equipped with the Krull topology in which the base of open neighborhoods of the identity is formed by normal subgroups of finite index. Therefore a continuous finite-dimensional complex representation of GF necessarily factors through a finite quotient of GF. To obtain a larger class of Galois representations we replace ‚ÑÇ with the field ‚Ñö‚Ñì of ‚Ñì‚Äìadic numbers, where ‚Ñì is a prime that does not divide q. Denote by ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì the algebraic closure of ‚Ñö‚Ñì. By an n‚Äìdimensional ‚Ñì‚Äìadic representation of GF we will understand a homomorphism œÉ:GF‚ÜíG‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì) which satisfies the following conditions:

  1. (1)

    there exists a finite extension E‚äÇ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì of ‚Ñö‚Ñì such that œÉ factors through a homomorphism GF‚ÜíG‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(E), which is continuous with respect to the Krull topology on GF and the ‚Ñì‚Äìadic topology on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(E);

  2. (2)

    it is unramified at all but finitely many x‚àà|X|.

Let ùí¢n be the set of equivalence classes of irreducible n‚Äìdimensional ‚Ñì‚Äìadic representations of GF such that the image of det‚Å°(œÉ) is a finite group.

Given such a representation, we consider the collection of the Frobenius conjugacy classes {œÉ‚Å¢(Frx)} in G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì) and the collection of their eigenvalues (defined up to permutation), which we denote by {(z1‚Å¢(œÉx),‚Ä¶,zn‚Å¢(œÉx))}, for all x‚àà|X| where œÉ is unramified. Chebotarev‚Äôs density theorem implies the following remarkable result: if two ‚Ñì‚Äìadic representations are such that their collections of the Frobenius conjugacy classes coincide for all but finitely many points x‚àà|X|, then these representations are equivalent.

2.2. Automorphic representations

Consider now the group G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). It carries a Haar measure normalized in such a way that the volume of the subgroup G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™x) is equal to 1 for all x‚àà|X|. Note that G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F) is naturally a subgroup of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). A function œÜ:G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)‚Üí‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì is called cuspidal automorphic if it satisfies the following conditions:

  1. (1)

    it is left G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)‚Äìinvariant;

  2. (2)

    it is right invariant with respect to an open subgroup of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏);

  3. (3)

    there exists an element a‚ààùî∏√ó of non-zero degree such that œÜ‚Å¢(a‚Å¢g)=œÜ‚Å¢(g) for all g‚ààG‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏);

  4. (4)

    let Nn1,n2 be the unipotent radical of the standard parabolic subgroup Pn1,n2 of G‚Å¢Ln corresponding to the partition n=n1+n2 with n1,n2>0. Then

    ‚à´Nn1,n2‚Å¢(F)\Nn1,n2‚Å¢(ùî∏)‚Å¢œÜ‚Å¢(u‚Å¢g)‚Å¢d‚Å¢u=0,‚àÄg‚ààG‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏).

Denote the vector space of cuspidal automorphic functions on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) by ùíûcusp. The group G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) acts on ùíûcusp, and under this action ùíûcusp decomposes into a direct sum of irreducible representations. These representations are called irreducible cuspidal automorphic representations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). A theorem due to Piatetski-Shapiro [PS1] and Shalika [Sh] says that the each of them enters ùíûcusp with multiplicity one. We denote the set of equivalence classes of these representations by ùíún.

Remark 2.1.

If œÄ1 and œÄ2 are irreducible representations of G‚Å¢Ln1‚Å¢(ùî∏) and G‚Å¢Ln2‚Å¢(ùî∏), respectively, where n1+n2=n, then we may extend trivially the representation œÄ1‚äóœÄ2 of G‚Å¢Ln1√óG‚Å¢Ln2 to the parabolic subgroup Pn1,n2‚Å¢(ùî∏) and consider the induced representation of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). It is easy to see that irreducible quotients of this representation cannot be realized in the space ùíûcusp because of the cuspidality condition (4). In fact, this condition is imposed precisely so as to avoid irreducible quotients of induced representations.

We also remark that condition (3) is equivalent to the central character of œÄ being of finite order.‚àé

Let œÄ be an irreducible cuspidal automorphic representation of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). One can show that it decomposes into a tensor product

œÄ=‚äóx‚àà|X|œÄx‚Ä≤,

where each œÄx is an irreducible representation of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(Fx). Furthermore, there is a finite subset S of |X| such that each œÄx with x‚àà|X|-S is unramified, i.e., contains a non-zero vector vx stable under the maximal compact subgroup G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™x) of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(Fx). This vector is unique up to a scalar and we will fix it once and for all. The space ‚äóx‚àà|X|‚Ä≤œÄx is by definition the span of all vectors of the form ‚äóx‚àà|X|wx, where wx‚ààœÄx and wx=vx for all but finitely many x‚àà|X|-S. Therefore the action of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) on œÄ is well-defined.

Let ‚Ñãx be the space of compactly supported functions on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(Fx) which are bi-invariant with respect to the subgroup G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™x). This is an algebra with respect to the convolution product, which is called the spherical Hecke algebra. By the Satake correspondence (see Theorem¬†5.1 below), we have an isomorphism

(2.1) ‚Ñãx‚âÉ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì‚Å¢[z1¬±1,‚Ä¶,zn¬±1]Sn.

The Hecke algebra ‚Ñãx naturally acts on any irreducible unramified representation œÄx of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(Fx) and preserves the one-dimensional subspace of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™x)‚Äìinvariant vectors spanned by vx. Hence ‚Ñãx acts on it via a character, which is nothing but a collection of non-zero numbers (z1‚Å¢(œÄx),‚Ä¶,zn‚Å¢(œÄx)) defined up to permutation. We will call them the Hecke eigenvalues of œÄ at x. Thus, to each irreducible cuspidal automorphic representation œÄ one associates a collection of Hecke eigenvalues {(z1‚Å¢(œÄx),‚Ä¶,zn‚Å¢(œÄx))}x‚àà|X|-S, defined up to permutation. The strong multiplicity one theorem due to Piatetski-Shapiro [PS1] says that this collection determines œÄ up to an isomorphism.

2.3. The Langlands correspondence and related results

Now we can state the Langlands conjecture for G‚Å¢Ln in the function field case. It has been proved by Drinfeld [Dr1, Dr2] for n=2 and by Lafforgue [Laf2] for n>2.

Theorem 2.2.

There is a bijection between the sets ùíún and ùí¢n defined above which satisfies the following condition. If œÄ‚ààùíún corresponds to œÉ‚ààùí¢n, then the sets of points where they are unramified are the same, and for each x from this set we have

(z1‚Å¢(œÄx),‚Ä¶,zn‚Å¢(œÄx))=(z1‚Å¢(œÉx),‚Ä¶,zn‚Å¢(œÉx))

up to permutation.

In other words, if œÄ and œÉ correspond to each other, then the Hecke eigenvalues of œÄ coincide with the Frobenius eigenvalues of œÉ at all points where they are unramified.

In addition to the Langlands correspondence, Drinfeld [Dr3] (for n=2) and Lafforgue [Laf1, Laf2] (for n>2) have also proved the following result.

Theorem 2.3.

At all points x‚àà|X| where œÄ‚ààùíún is unramified, the Hecke eigenvalues zi‚Å¢(œÄx) of œÄ are algebraic numbers with (complex) absolute value equal to 1.

Remark 2.4.

The statement saying that |zi‚Å¢(œÄx)|=1 is called the Ramanujan-Petersson conjecture. Its classical analogue is the Ramanujan conjecture, proved by Deligne, that the coefficients œÑ‚Å¢(n) of the Ramanujan œÑ‚Äìfunction

q‚Å¢‚àèm=1(1-qm)24=‚àën=1‚àûœÑ‚Å¢(n)‚Å¢qn

satisfy the relation |œÑ‚Å¢(p)|‚â§2‚Å¢p11/2 for a prime p. It turns out that the numbers œÑ‚Å¢(p) may be written in the form

(2.2) œÑ‚Å¢(p)=p11/2‚Å¢(Œ±p+Œ≤p)

where Œ±p and Œ≤p=Œ±¬Øp are the Hecke eigenvalues of an automorphic representation of G‚Å¢L2‚Å¢(ùî∏‚Ñö) corresponding to the modular form œÑ‚Å¢(q) and therefore the Ramanujan conjecture is equivalent to the statement that |Œ±p|=|Œ≤p|=1, which is analogous to the condition appearing in Theorem¬†2.3.‚àé

Theorem¬†2.3 has a stunning corollary, known as the Deligne purity conjecture [De2]. Let V be a normal algebraic variety over ùîΩq. Then one defines, in the same way as above in the case of curves, ‚Ñì‚Äìadic representations of the Galois group Gal‚Å°(F¬Ø/F), where F is the field of rational functions on V and F¬Ø is its separable closure. The following theorem is proved by reducing the statement to the case where V is a curve and applying Theorems 2.2 and 2.3.

Theorem 2.5.

Let œÉ be any irreducible ‚Ñì‚Äìadic representation of Gal‚Å°(F¬Ø/F), which is everywhere unramified and has determinant of finite order. Then the eigenvalues of the Frobenius conjugacy classes at all closed points of V are algebraic numbers with (complex) absolute value 1.

3. Elements of the proof of the Langlands conjecture

In this section we discuss some of the ideas and constructions involved in the proof of the Langlands correspondence, Theorem¬†2.2, by Drinfeld and Lafforgue. In the first approximation, one can say that the main idea is to realize this correspondence in the cohomology of a certain moduli space of vector bundles on X with some additional structures, called ‚Äúshtukas‚Äù, and to use the Grothendieck‚ÄìLefschetz formula to relate the traces of Hecke correspondences acting on this cohomology with the numbers of fixed points of these correspondences acting on the moduli space.

3.1. From automorphic functions to vector bundles

Recall that automorphic representations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) are realized in the space ùíûcusp of functions on the quotient G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). Suppose that we are given an automorphic representation œÄ of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) which is unramified at all points of X. Then the space of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™)‚Äìinvariants in œÄ, where ùí™=‚àèx‚àà|X|ùí™x, is one-dimensional, spanned by the vector

v=‚äóx‚àà|X|vx,

where vx is defined in Section¬†2.2. Hence v gives rise to a G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™)‚Äìinvariant function on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏), or equivalently, a function on the double quotient

G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)/G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™).

The following key observation is due to A. Weil.

Lemma 3.1.

There is a bijection between the set G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)/G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™) and the set of isomorphism classes of rank n vector bundles on X.

Proof.

Any rank n bundle on X may be trivialized on the formal disc Dx=Spec‚Å°ùí™x around each point x‚àà|X| and over X-S, where S is a sufficiently large subset of |X|, hence over the generic point Xgen=Spec‚Å°F of X.

Let B be the set of isomorphism classes of the data (‚Ñ≥,œÜgen,(œÜx)), where ‚Ñ≥ is a rank n bundle on X, and œÜgen and œÜx,x‚àà|X|, are the trivializations of ‚Ñ≥ over the generic point of X and the formal discs Dx, respectively, i.e., isomorphisms œÜgen:Fn‚Å¢‚Üí‚àº‚Å¢Œì‚Å¢(Xgen,‚Ñ≥), œÜx:ùí™xn‚Å¢‚Üí‚àº‚Å¢Œì‚Å¢(Dx,‚Ñ≥). The restrictions of œÜgen and œÜx to the punctured disc Dx√ó=Spec‚Å°ùí¶x then give us two different trivializations of ‚Ñ≥|Dx√ó, which we denote by the same symbols. Let gx=œÜgen-1‚àòœÜx be the corresponding transition function, which is an element of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí¶x).

Consider the map b:B‚ÜíG‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) sending (‚Ñ≥,œÜgen,(œÜx)) to (gx)x‚àà|X|‚ààG‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). It is easy to see that this map is a bijection. Therefore there is bijection between the set of isomorphism classes of rank n bundles on X and the quotient of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) by the equivalence relations corresponding to changes of the trivializations œÜgen and œÜx,x‚àà|X|. These equivalence relations amount to the left action of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F) and the right action of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™) on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏), respectively. Hence we obtain the statement of the lemma. ‚àé

In order to apply the machinery of algebraic geometry one needs to interpret sets like G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)/G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™) as sets of points of algebraic varieties over ùîΩq. Once this is done, one can use things like cohomology groups of varieties and techniques like the Lefschetz fixed point formula. The above result gives precisely such an interpretation of the double quotient G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)/G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™). Namely, we obtain that it is the set of ùîΩq‚Äìpoints of the moduli space Bunn of rank n vector bundles on X. To be precise, Bunn is not an algebraic variety, but an algebraic stack, which means, roughly speaking, that it looks locally like an algebraic variety quotiented out by the action of an algebraic group (these actions are not free, and therefore the quotient is no longer an algebraic variety), see [LMB] for the precise definition. But for our purposes this turns out to be sufficient.

3.2. Hecke correspondences

A general cuspidal automorphic representation œÄ is unramified away from a finite set of points S‚äÇ|X|, but for each x‚ààS there exists a compact subgroup Kx such that the space of Kx‚Äìinvariants in œÄx is non-zero. In a similar fashion to Lemma¬†3.1 one identifies this double quotient with the set of ùîΩq‚Äìpoints of the moduli stack Bunn,N of rank n vector bundles ‚Ñ≥ on X together with the level structure at N, that is a trivialization of the restriction of ‚Ñ≥ to N, considered as a finite subscheme of X. The Hecke algebra ‚ÑãNn of compactly supported functions on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) bi-invariant with respect to KN acts on the space of functions on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)/KN preserving its subspace œÄKN. This action may also be described in terms of Hecke correspondences in Bunn,N√óBunn,N as in the unramified case.

3.3. Deligne‚Äôs recurrence scheme

The starting point of the proof of the Langlands correspondence is the following recurrence scheme originally suggested by P. Deligne.

Theorem 3.2.

Suppose that for each n‚Ä≤=1,‚Ä¶,n-1 we have a map œÅn‚Ä≤:ùíún‚Ä≤‚Üíùí¢n‚Ä≤ such that for each œÄ‚ààùíún‚Ä≤ the Frobenius eigenvalues of œÅn‚Ä≤‚Å¢(œÄ) coincide with the Hecke eigenvalues of œÄ at all points where œÄ and œÅn‚Ä≤‚Å¢(œÄ) are unramified. Then there exists a map œïn:ùí¢n‚Üíùíún such that for each œÉ‚ààùí¢n the Frobenius eigenvalues of œÉ coincide with the Hecke eigenvalues of œïn‚Å¢(œÉ) at all points where œÉ and œïn‚Å¢(œÉ) are unramified.

The proof is based on several deep results: Grothendieck‚Äôs functional equation for the L‚Äìfunctions associated to ‚Ñì‚Äìadic Galois representations [Gr], Laumon‚Äôs product formula for the œµ‚Äìconstant appearing in this functional equation [La1], and the ‚Äúconverse theorems‚Äù of Hecke, Weil and Piatetski-Shapiro [PS1, CPS]. We refer the reader to [La1] and [Laf2] for more details.

The Langlands correspondence is known for n=1 by the abelian class field theory. Therefore, in view of Theorem¬†3.2, in order to establish the Langlands correspondence for all n>1 it is sufficient to construct maps œÅn:ùíún‚Üíùí¢n satisfying the conditions of Theorem¬†3.2 for all n>1. How can this be achieved?

A naive idea is to construct a natural representation of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)√óGF defined over ‚Ñö‚Ñì which decomposes (over ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì) into a direct sum

‚äïœÄ‚ààùíúnœÄ‚äóœÉœÄ,

where each œÉœÄ is an irreducible n‚Äìdimensional ‚Ñì‚Äìadic representation of GF. Then if the Hecke eigenvalues of œÄ and Frobenius eigenvalues of œÉœÄ coincide, we can construct the map œÅn by the formula œÄ‚Ü¶œÉœÄ. Unfortunately, such a representation of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)√óGF does not exist (this is explained in [Kaz]). Instead, Drinfeld proposed to construct a representation of the product G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)√óGF√óGF which decomposes as

‚äïœÄ‚ààùíúnœÄ‚äóœÉœÄ‚äóœÉœÄ‚à®,

where œÉœÄ‚à® denotes the representation contragredient to œÉœÄ (here and below we will be ignoring the Tate twists).

Drinfeld (for n=2) and Lafforgue (for n>2) have constructed such a representation in the ‚Äúessential‚Äù part of the direct limit of the middle ‚Ñì‚Äìadic cohomologies of the moduli spaces of shtukas with level structures. In the next section we will introduce these moduli spaces.

3.4. Moduli spaces of shtukas

As is well-known by now, ‚Äúshtuka‚Äù is a Russian word that may be loosely translated as a ‚Äúwidget‚Äù. This term was used by Drinfeld for the following objects that he introduced.

First note that the Frobenius endomorphism Fr of ùîΩq defined by the formula y‚Ü¶yq induces a map Id√óFr:X¬Ø‚ÜíX¬Ø, where X¬Ø=X‚Å¢√óSpec‚Å°ùîΩq‚Å¢Spec‚Å°ùîΩ¬Øq. Given a vector bundle ‚Ñ∞ on X¬Ø, we denote by ‚Ñ∞œÑ the vector bundle (Id√óFr)*‚Å¢(‚Ñ∞).

Recall that the skyscraper sheaf supported at z‚ààX¬Ø is the coherent sheaf whose stalk at y‚ààX¬Ø is one-dimensional if y=z and is equal to 0 if y‚â†z.

Definition 3.3.

A shtuka of rank n on X¬Ø is a vector bundle ‚Ñ∞ of rank n on X¬Ø together with a diagram

‚Ñ∞‚Å¢‚Ü™ùëó‚Å¢‚Ñ∞‚Ä≤‚Å¢‚Ü©ùë°‚Å¢‚Ñ∞œÑ

where ‚Ñ∞‚Ä≤ is another rank n vector bundle on X¬Ø and t,j are injections of the corresponding sheaves of sections such that their cokernels are the skyscraper sheaves supported at the points 0,‚àû‚ààX¬Ø, called the zero and the pole of the shtuka, respectively.

Note that a vector bundle ‚Ñ∞ on X¬Ø equipped with an isomorphism ‚Ñ∞œÑ‚âÉ‚Ñ∞ is the same thing as a vector bundle on X. So a shtuka is a mild generalization of the notion of vector bundle on X. Indeed, for any shtuka the bundles ‚Ñ∞œÑ and ‚Ñ∞ are isomorphic over X¬Ø-{0,‚àû} and they differ in the simplest possible way at the points 0 and ‚àû.

The reader may find more information on shtukas and closely related objects, Drinfeld modules, including explicit examples, in [Go].

Let N=Spec‚Å°ùí™N be a finite subscheme of X (equivalently, a divisor on X). A shtuka with level structure N is a shtuka ‚Ñ∞~=(‚Ñ∞,‚Ñ∞‚Ä≤,j,t) such that the points 0 and ‚àû avoid N, together with a trivialization of the restriction of ‚Ñ∞ to N, i.e., an isomorphism ‚Ñ∞‚Å¢‚äóùí™X¬Ø‚Å¢ùí™N¬Ø‚âÉùí™N¬Ø‚äïn so that the induced trivialization of the restriction of ‚Ñ∞œÑ to N is compatible with the isomorphism

t‚àòj:‚Ñ∞|X¬Ø\{0,‚àû}‚Å¢‚Üí‚àº‚Å¢‚Ñ∞œÑ|X¬Ø\{0,‚àû}.

One defines similarly shtukas over X√óS, where S is any scheme over ùîΩq. This enables one to define an algebraic stack ChtNn classifying shtukas of rank n with level structure at N on X. Drinfeld proved that this is a smooth Deligne-Mumford stack, which means, roughly, that locally it looks like the quotient of a smooth algebraic variety by the action of a finite group. It is equipped with a natural morphism to (X-N)√ó(X-N) (taking the pole and zero of a shtuka) of relative dimension 2‚Å¢n-2. It carries the action of the ‚Äúpartial‚Äù Frobenius endomorphisms Frob0 and Frob‚àû corresponding to the zero and pole of the shtuka. In the same way as in Section¬†3.1 one defines Hecke correspondences in ChtNn‚Å°√ó(|X|-N)2‚Å¢ChtNn which realize the Hecke algebra ‚ÑãNn of compactly supported functions on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) bi-invariant with respect to KN.

In addition, one has a natural action on ChtNn of the Picard group of line bundles on X (by tensoring with ‚Ñ∞ and ‚Ñ∞‚Ä≤). Lemma¬†3.1 implies that the Picard group is isomorphic to the quotient F√ó\ùî∏√ó/ùí™√ó. Let us pick an element a of degree 1 in ùî∏√ó. Lafforgue denotes the quotient of ChtNn by the action of the cyclic group generated by the corresponding line bundle by ChtNn/a‚Ñ§. This algebraic stack still carries the above actions of Frob0,Frob‚àû and ‚ÑãNn.

3.5. Strategy of the proof

Let q‚Ä≤,q‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ be the two projections X2‚ÜíX. For each representation œÉ of GF we obtain by pull-back two representations, q‚Ä≤(œÉ)* and q‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(œÉ)* of the Galois group GF~ of the field F~ of functions on X2. Consider the ‚Ñì‚Äìadic cohomology with compact support of ChtNn/a‚Ñ§, over the generic point of X√óX. This is naturally a representation of the Hecke algebra ‚ÑãNn and of GF~, whose actions commute with each other. We would like to isolate in this cohomology a subspace that decomposes as

(3.1) ‚äïœÄ‚ààùíún,NaœÄN‚äóq‚Ä≤(œÉœÄ)*‚äóq‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(œÉœÄ‚à®)*,

where œÄN is the space of KN‚Äìinvariants in œÄ, each œÉœÄ is an irreducible n‚Äìdimensional ‚Ñì‚Äìadic representation of GF unramified in |X|-N, and ùíún,Na is a subset of ùíún,N, which consists of those representations on which a‚ààG‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) acts as the identity. If we could show that the Hecke eigenvalues of each œÄ in the above formula coincide with the Frobenius eigenvalues of œÉœÄ, then in view of the discussion at the end of Section¬†3.3, this would prove the Langlands correspondence.

Suppose we could isolate this subspace in the cohomology. Then we would need to compute the traces of the operators of the form f√ó(Frob0)s√ó(Frob‚àû)s on this subspace, where f‚àà‚ÑãNn and 0,‚àû‚àà|X-N|. If we could establish that these traces are equal to

(3.2) ‚àëœÄ‚ààùíún,NaTrœÄN(f)(z1(œÄ‚àû)-s/deg‚Å°(‚àû)+‚Ä¶+zn(œÄ‚àû)-s/deg‚Å°(‚àû))√ó(z1‚Å¢(œÄ0)s/deg‚Å°(0)+‚Ä¶+zn‚Å¢(œÄ0)s/deg‚Å°(0)),

then it would not be difficult to prove that our space is indeed isomorphic to (3.1) with all the required compatibilities. But how could we possibly identify the trace over the cohomology with the sum (3.2)?

First of all, we need to apply the Grothendieck-Lefschetz fixed point formula. It expresses the alternating sum of the traces of correspondences over ‚Ñì‚Äìadic cohomologies of a smooth variety as the number of the fixed points of these correspondences. Suppose we could apply this formula to the correspondences f√ó(Frob0)s√ó(Frob‚àû)s acting on ChtNn/a‚Ñ§. We should then compare the number of fixed points appearing in this formula with the Arthur-Selberg trace formula. This formula describes the traces of the operators like f‚àà‚ÑãNn on the space ùíûcusp=‚äïœÄ‚ààùíúnœÄ of cuspidal automorphic functions in terms of orbital integrals in G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏). We may hope to relate these orbital integrals to the numbers of fixed points in the moduli spaces of shtukas. That would give us the desired expression for the trace of our correspondences acting on the ‚Ñì‚Äìadic cohomology as the sum (3.2).

3.6. From a dream to reality

This is the general strategy of Drinfeld and Lafforgue. Unfortunately, literally it cannot work, because ChtNn/a‚Ñ§ is not (quasi)compact: it cannot be covered by finitely many open subsets of finite type. For this reason its cohomology is infinite-dimensional and there are infintely many fixed points, and so one cannot apply the Grothendieck-Lefschetz formula. To remedy this, Lafforgue introduces open substacks ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§ of finite type in ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§. They are labeled by ‚ÄúHarder-Narasimhan polygons‚Äù p:[0,n]‚Üí‚Ñù+. Furthermore, using the Arthur-Selberg trace formula (see [Laf1]) Lafforgue computes the numbers of fixed points of the correspondences f√ó(Frob0)s√ó(Frob‚àû)s in the set of ùîΩq‚Äìpoints of ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§. The answer is the expression (3.2) plus the the sum of terms that correspond to representations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) induced from parabolic subgroups (i.e., those which are not cuspidal).

The problem however is that (except for the case when it is equal to the identity) the correspondence f does not stabilize the open subset ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§. Therefore we cannot interpret the number of fixed points as the trace over the cohomology of ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§. To fix this problem, Lafforgue (and Drinfeld for n=2) introduced compactifications ChtNn,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§ of ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§ by allowing certain degenerations of shtukas. The Hecke correspondences can now be extended to ChtNn,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§. Unfortunately, the compactifications ChtNn,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§ are singular (unless N=‚àÖ). Therefore a priori these Hecke correspondences do not induce linear operators on the cohomologies of ChtNn,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§.

In the case when n=2, Drinfeld has shown that ChtN2,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§ is quasi-smooth, i.e., its cohomology exhibits Poincar√© duality. Therefore the Hecke correspondences act on the cohomology of ChtN2,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§, and Drinfeld was able to relate their traces to the numbers of fixed points. This allowed him to prove that the cuspidal part of the middle (second in this case) cohomology of ChtN2,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§ indeed decomposes according to formula (3.1) and hence realizes the Langlands correspondence for G‚Å¢L2.

For n>2 the stacks ChtNn,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§ are no longer quasi-smooth in general. To deal with this problem Lafforgue introduced another open subset ChtNn,p¬Ø‚Ä≤/a‚Ñ§ of ChtNn,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§ defined by the condition that the degenerations of the shtuka avoid N. The stack ChtNn,p¬Ø‚Ä≤/a‚Ñ§ is smooth and its complement in ChtNn,p¬Ø/a‚Ñ§ is a divisor with normal crossings. Moreover, it turns out that the (normalized) Hecke correspondences defined in ChtNn,p¬Ø‚Ä≤/a‚Ñ§ stabilize ChtNn,p¬Ø‚Ä≤/a‚Ñ§.

Thus, Lafforgue ended up with three different objects, each with some ‚Äúgood‚Äù and ‚Äúbad‚Äù properties. Indeed, ChtNn/a‚Ñ§ carries an action of the Hecke algebra by correspondences, but is not of finite type. The stacks ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§ are of finite type and it is possible to compute the numbers of fixed points of the Hecke correspondences there, but the correspondences themselves do not preserve them. Finally, on ChtNn,p¬Ø‚Ä≤/a‚Ñ§ one can write down the Grothendieck-Lefschetz formula for the Hecke correspondences, but it is not clear how to compute either side of this formula.

Lafforgue‚Äôs ingenious trick is to separate inside the cohomology with compact support of all three objects the ‚Äúessential‚Äù part and the ‚Äúnegligible‚Äù part and to show that the ‚Äúessential‚Äù part is the same for all of them. Namely, the negligible part consists of those representations of GF~ which appear as direct factors in the tensor products of the form q‚Ä≤(œÉ‚Ä≤)*‚äóq‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(œÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)*, where œÉ‚Ä≤ and œÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ are GF‚Äìrepresentations of dimension less than n. The rest is the essential part.

In order to compute this essential part, Lafforgue needed to overcome some formidable technical difficulties. The original Grothendieck-Lefschetz formula is applicable when we have a smooth proper algebraic variety. Here ChtNn,p¬Ø‚Ä≤/a‚Ñ§ is not a variety but an algebraic stack which is not even proper. Building upon earlier works of Pink and Fujiwara on the Deligne conjecture, Lafforgue proved a new version of the Grothendieck-Lefschetz formula which enabled him to express the trace of a Hecke correspondence and a power of the Frobenius endomorphism on the cohomology of ChtNn,p¬Ø‚Ä≤/a‚Ñ§ as the number of fixed points in ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§ plus a sum of terms corresponding to various boundary strata in the complement of ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§. By a complicated recurrence argument on n he showed that the latter are all negligible. Therefore he was able to identify the traces of the Hecke operators and the Frobenius endomorphisms acting on the essential part of the middle cohomology with compact support of ChtNn,p/a‚Ñ§ (which coincides with that of ChtNn,p¬Ø‚Ä≤/a‚Ñ§) with formula (3.2). This completed his proof of the Langlands correspondence for G‚Å¢Ln.

In addition, he proved Theorem¬†2.3, because the Frobenius eigenvalues of irreducible representations of GF are now realized as traces of Frobenius endomorphisms acting on ‚Ñì‚Äìadic cohomology, so that one can apply Deligne‚Äôs results on Weil‚Äôs conjectures [De1, De2].

4. The geometric Langlands conjecture

The geometric reformulation of the Langlands conjecture allows one to state it for curves defined over an arbitrary field, not just a finite field. For instance, it may be stated for complex curves, and in this setting one can apply methods of complex algebraic geometry which are unavailable over finite fields. Hopefully, this will eventually help us understand better the general underlying patterns of the Langlands correspondence. In this section we will formulate the geometric Langlands conjecture for G‚Å¢Ln and discuss briefly its recent proof due to D. Gaitsgory, K. Vilonen and the author.

4.1. Galois representations as local systems

What needs to be done to reformulate the Langlands conjecture geometrically?

As we indicated in Section¬†2.1, the Galois group GF should be viewed as a kind of fundamental group, and so its ‚Ñì‚Äìadic representations unramified away from a divisor N should be viewed as local systems on X-N. This is indeed possible if one defines local systems in terms of ‚Ñì‚Äìadic sheaves.

Let us discuss them briefly. Let V be an algebraic variety over ùîΩq, and ‚Ñì a prime which does not divide q. Then one defines the category of ‚Ñì‚Äìadic sheaves on V. The construction involves several steps (see, e.g., [Mi, FK]). First one considers locally constant ‚Ñ§/‚Ñìm‚Å¢‚Ñ§‚Äìsheaves on V in the √©tale topology (in which the role of open subsets is played by √©tale morphisms U‚ÜíV). A ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äìsheaf on V is by definition a system (‚Ñ±m) of locally constant ‚Ñ§/‚Ñìm‚Å¢‚Ñ§‚Äìsheaves satisfying natural compatibilities. Then one defines the category of ‚Ñö‚Ñì‚Äìsheaves by killing the torsion sheaves in the category of ‚Ñ§‚Ñì‚Äìsheaves. In a similar fashion one defines the category of E‚Äìsheaves on V, where E is a finite extension of ‚Ñö‚Ñì. Finally, one takes the direct limit of the categories of E‚Äìsheaves on X, and the objects of this category are called the lisse ‚Ñì‚Äìadic sheaves on V, or ‚Ñì‚Äìadic local systems. An ‚Ñì‚Äìadic local system on X-N of rank n is the same as an n‚Äìdimensional ‚Ñì‚Äìadic representation of GF unramified everywhere on X-N.

Thus, we can now interpret Galois representations geometrically: these are ‚Ñì‚Äìadic local systems on X. The notion of local system makes sense if X is defined over other fields. For example, if X is a smooth projective curve over ‚ÑÇ, a local system is a vector bundle on X with a flat connection, or equivalently, a homomorphism from the fundamental group œÄ1‚Å¢(X) to G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(‚ÑÇ).

4.2. From functions to sheaves

Next, we wish to interpret geometrically automorphic representations. Let us restrict ourselves to unramified representations. As we explained in Section¬†3.1, one can attach to such a representation œÄ a non-zero function fœÄ (unique up to a scalar) on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)/G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™), which is an eigenfunction of the Hecke algebras ‚Ñãx,x‚àà|X|. In fact, this function completely determines the representation œÄ, so instead of considering the set of equivalence classes of unramified cuspidal representations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏), one may consider the set of unramified automorphic functions associated to them (defined up to a scalar).

The key step in the geometric reformulation of this notion is the Grothendieck fonctions‚Äìfaisceaux dictionary. Let V be an algebraic variety over ùîΩq. One generalizes the above definition of an ‚Ñì‚Äìadic local system on V by allowing the ‚Ñ§/‚Ñìn‚Å¢‚Ñ§‚Äìsheaves ‚Ñ±n to be constructible, i.e., for which there exists a stratification of V by locally closed subvarieties Vi such that the sheaves ‚Ñ±|Vi are locally constant. As a result, one obtains the notion of a constructible ‚Ñì‚Äìadic sheaf on V, or an ‚Ñì‚Äìadic sheaf, for brevity. Let ‚Ñ± be such a sheaf and x be an ùîΩq1‚Äìpoint of V, where q1=qm. Then one has the Frobenius conjugacy class Frx acting on the stalk ‚Ñ±x of ‚Ñ± at x. Hence we can define a function ùöèq1‚Å¢(‚Ñ±) on the set of ùîΩq1‚Äìpoints of V, whose value at x is Tr‚Å°(Frx,‚Ñ±x).

More generally, if ùí¶ is a complex of ‚Ñì‚Äìadic sheaves, one defines a function ùöèq1‚Å¢(ùí¶) on V‚Å¢(ùîΩq1) by taking the alternating sums of the traces of Frx on the stalk cohomologies of ùí¶ at x. The map ùí¶‚Üíùöèq1‚Å¢(ùí¶) intertwines the natural operations on sheaves with natural operations on functions (see [La1], Sect. 1.2). For example, pull-back of a sheaf corresponds to the pull-back of a function, and push-forward of a sheaf with compact support corresponds to the fiberwise integration of a function (this follows from the Grothendieck-Lefschetz trace formula).

We wish to identify a natural abelian category in the derived category of ‚Ñì‚Äìadic sheaves such that the map ùí¶‚Ü¶(ùöèq1‚Å¢(ùí¶))q1=qm is injective. The naive category of ‚Ñì‚Äìadic sheaves is not a good choice for various reasons; for instance, it is not stable under the Verdier duality. The correct choice is the abelian category of perverse sheaves. These are complexes of ‚Ñì‚Äìadic sheaves on V satisfying certain restrictions on the degrees of their non-zero stalk cohomologies (see [BBD]). Examples are ‚Ñì‚Äìadic local systems on a smooth variety V, placed in the cohomological degree equal to -dim‚Å°V. Unlike ordinary sheaves, the perverse sheaves have the following remarkable property: an irreducible perverse sheaf on a variety V is completely determined by its restriction to an arbitrary open dense subset, provided that this restriction is non-zero.

Optimistically, one can hope that all ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù functions on V‚Å¢(ùîΩq1) come from perverse sheaves by taking the traces of the Frobeniuses (or is it Frobenii?). Unramified automorphic functions on G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)/G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™) are certainly ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù. Therefore one hopes that they all come from perverse sheaves on the moduli stack Bunn, whose set of points is G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)/G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™), according to Lemma¬†3.1.

Thus, we have identified the geometric objects which should replace unramified automorphic functions: these are perverse sheaves on Bunn. This concept also makes sense if X is defined over other fields, for example, the field of complex numbers (see, e.g., [GM]).

4.3. Hecke eigensheaves and the geometric Langlands conjecture

But how to formulate the Hecke eigenfunction condition which unramified automorphic functions satisfy in sheaf-theoretic terms? The key is the description of the Hecke operators in terms of the Hecke correspondences that was explained in Section¬†3.1. We use these correspondences to define the Hecke functors Hi from the category of perverse sheaves on Bunn to the derived category of sheaves on X√óBunn by the formula (here and below we will ignore cohomological shifts and Tate twists)

The statement of this conjecture was proved by Deligne for G‚Å¢L1 (we recall it in the next section) and by Drinfeld in the case of G‚Å¢L2 [Dr4]. These works motivated the conjecture in the case of G‚Å¢Ln, which has recently been proved in [FGV, Ga]. So we now have the following result, in which X is a smooth projective connected curve defined either over a finite field or over the field of complex numbers. As before, we denote by Bunn the moduli stack of rank n bundles on X. It is a disjoint union of connected components Bunnd corresponding to vector bundles of degree d.

Theorem 4.2.

For each irreducible rank n local system E on X there exists a perverse sheaf AutE on Bunn, irreducible on each connected component Bunnd, which is a Hecke eigensheaf with respect to E.

4.4. Geometric abelian class field theory

Let us consider Deligne‚Äôs proof of the n=1 case of Theorem¬†4.2 (see [La2]). In this case B‚Å¢u‚Å¢nnd is essentially the component Picd of the Picard variety Pic of X classifying the line bundles on X of degree d. Let us consider the case when X is defined over a finite field. Then to the sheaf AutE we attach a function on F√ó\ùî∏√ó/ùí™√ó, which is the set of ùîΩq‚Äìpoints of Pic. It is instructive to contrast this to Deligne‚Äôs geometric proof reproduced above. 4.5. The idea of the proof for general n

Observe that for large d the variety Sd‚Å¢X may be interpreted as the moduli space Bun1‚Ä≤ of pairs (‚Ñí,s), where ‚Ñí is a line bundle on X and s is its section. We first constructed a Hecke eigensheaf on Bun1‚Ä≤ and then showed that it descends to Bun1. This is the main idea of the construction of AutE for general n as well.

At the level of functions this construction is due to Weil [W] and Jacquet-Langlands [JL] for n=2, and Shalika [Sh] and Piatetski-Shapiro [PS1] for general n. They attach to an unramified n‚Äìdimensional representation œÉ of GF, a function fœÉ‚Ä≤ on the set of isomorphism classes of pairs (‚Ñ≥,s), where ‚Ñ≥‚ààBunn is a rank n bundle on X and s is a regular non-zero section of ‚Ñ≥. Then it remains to show that this function is independent of the section, i.e., descends to the the set of isomorphism classes of rank n bundles on X, which is the double quotient G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(F)\G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏)/G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùí™).

We reformulate this geometrically. Let Bunn‚Ä≤ be the moduli stack of pairs (‚Ñ≥,s), where ‚Ñ≥ is a rank n bundle on X and s is a regular non-zero section of L. Let E be an irreducible rank n local system on X. Building on the ideas of Drinfeld‚Äôs work [Dr4], Laumon gave a conjectural construction of the Hecke eigensheaf AutE in [La2, La3]. More precisely, he attached to each rank n local system E on X a complex of perverse sheaves AutE‚Ä≤ on Bunn‚Ä≤ and conjectured that if E is irreducible then this sheaf descends to a perverse sheaf AutE on Bunn (irreducible on each component), which is a Hecke eigensheaf with respect to E.

In the paper [FGKV] it was shown that the function on the set of points Bunn‚Ä≤‚Å°(ùîΩq) associated to AutE‚Ä≤ agrees with the function fœÉ‚Ä≤ constructed previously, as anticipated by Laumon [La3]. This provided a consistency check for Laumon‚Äôs construction. Next, in [FGV], Gaitsgory, Vilonen and myself formulated a certain vanishing conjecture and proved that Laumon‚Äôs construction indeed produces a perverse sheaf AutE on Bunn with the desired properties whenever the vanishing conjecture holds for E. In other words, the vanishing conjecture implies the geometric Langlands conjecture, for curves over any field. Moreover, in the case when this field is ùîΩq, we derived the vanishing conjecture (and hence the geometric Langlands conjecture) from the results of Lafforgue [Laf2]. Finally, Gaitsgory [Ga] gave another proof of the vanishing conjecture, valid for curves both over ùîΩq and over ‚ÑÇ. In the next section we will state this vanishing conjecture.
