The following theorem was stated as a conjecture in [FGV] and proved in [FGV] (when X is defined over a finite field) and in [Ga] (when X is defined over a finite field or over ‚ÑÇ).

Theorem 4.3.

Let E be an irreducible local system of rank n on X. Then for all k=1,‚Ä¶,n-1 and all d satisfying d>k‚Å¢n‚Å¢(2‚Å¢g-2), the functor Hk,Ed is identically equal to 0.

The geometric Langlands conjecture for G‚Å¢Ln follows from this theorem together with the main theorem of [FGV] which states that if Theorem¬†4.3 holds for an irreducible rank n local system E, then the geometric Langlands Conjecture¬†4.2 also holds for E.

In the case when k=1 Theorem¬†4.3 has been proved earlier by Deligne, and this result was one of the main steps in Drinfeld‚Äôs proof of the geometric Langlands conjecture for G‚Å¢L2 [Dr4]. In this case the result may be reformulated without using Laumon‚Äôs sheaf. Recall the Abel-Jacobi map œÄd:Sd‚Å¢X‚ÜíPicd introduced in Section¬†4.4. Then for any irreducible rank n>1 local system E on X we have

œÄd‚Å£*‚Å¢(E(d))=0,‚àÄd>n‚Å¢(2‚Å¢g-2).

It is not difficult to show that this statement is equivalent to the following result: H‚àô‚Å¢(Sd‚Å¢X,(E‚äóE‚Ä≤)(d))=0 for any rank one local system E‚Ä≤ on X. To prove that, observe that since E is irreducible and has rank n>1, so is E‚äóE‚Ä≤. Therefore we have H0‚Å¢(X,E‚äóE‚Ä≤)=H2‚Å¢(X,E‚äóE‚Ä≤)=0. But then by the K√ºnneth formula we have

H‚àô‚Å¢(Sd‚Å¢X,(E‚äóE‚Ä≤)(d))=‚àßdH1‚Å¢(X,E‚äóE‚Ä≤).

Note that dim‚Å°H1‚Å¢(X,E‚äóE‚Ä≤)=n‚Å¢(2‚Å¢g-2), which follows immediately from the computation of the Euler characteristic of H‚àô‚Å¢(X,E0), where E0 is the trivial local system of rank n. Therefore

H‚àô‚Å¢(Sd‚Å¢X,(E‚äóE‚Ä≤)(d))=0,‚àÄd>n‚Å¢(2‚Å¢g-2),

which is what we needed to prove.

5. From G‚Å¢Ln to other reductive groups

One adds a new dimension to the Langlands Program by considering arbitrary reductive groups instead of the group G‚Å¢Ln. This is when some of the most beautiful and mysterious aspects of the Program are revealed, such as the appearance of the Langlands dual group. In this section we will trace the appearance of the dual group in the classical context and then talk about its geometrization/categorification.

5.1. The spherical Hecke algebra for an arbitrary reductive group

Suppose we want to find an analogue of the Langlands correspondence from Theorem¬†2.2 where instead of automorphic representations of G‚Å¢Ln‚Å¢(ùî∏) we consider automorphic representations of G‚Å¢(ùî∏), where G is a (connected, split) reductive group over ùîΩq. We wish to relate those representations to some data corresponding to the Galois group GF. In the case of G‚Å¢Ln this relation satisfies an important compatibility condition that the Hecke eigenvalues of an automorphic representation coincide with the Frobenius eigenvalues of the corresponding Galois representation. Now we need to find an analogue of this compatibility condition for general reductive groups. The first step is to understand the structure of the spherical Hecke algebra ‚Ñãx. For G=G‚Å¢Ln we saw that this algebra is isomorphic to the algebra of symmetric Laurent polynomials in n variables. Now we need to give a similar description of ‚Ñãx for a general group G.

So let G be a connected reductive group over a finite field ùîΩq which is split over ùîΩq, i.e., contains a maximal torus T which is isomorphic to a power of the multiplicative group. Then we attach to this torus two lattices, P and P‚à®, or characters and cocharacters, respectively. They contain subsets Œî and Œî‚à® of roots and coroots of G, respectively (see [Sp] for more details). Let us pick a point x‚àà|X| and assume for simplicity that its residue field is ùîΩq. To simplify notation we will omit the index x from our formulas in this section. Thus, we will write ‚Ñã,F,ùí™ for ‚Ñãx,Fx,ùí™x, etc.

The Hecke algebra ‚Ñã=‚Ñã‚Å¢(G‚Å¢(F),G‚Å¢(ùí™)) is by definition the space of ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì‚Äìvalued compactly supported functions on G‚Å¢(F) which are bi-invariant with respect to the maximal compact subgroup G‚Å¢(ùí™). It is equipped with the convolution product

(5.1) (f1‚ãÖf2)‚Å¢(g)=‚à´Gf1‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢f2‚Å¢(g‚Å¢x-1)‚Å¢ùëëx,

where d‚Å¢x is the Haar measure on G‚Å¢(F) normalized so that the volume of G‚Å¢(ùí™) is equal to 1.

We have a natural restriction homomorphism ‚Ñã‚Üí‚Ñã‚Å¢(T‚Å¢(F),T‚Å¢(ùí™)). The Hecke algebra ‚Ñã‚Å¢(T‚Å¢(F),T‚Å¢(ùí™)) is easy to describe. For each Œª‚ààP‚à® we have an element Œª‚Å¢(t)‚ààT‚Å¢(F), where t is a uniformizer in ùí™, and T‚Å¢(ùí™)\T‚Å¢(F)/T‚Å¢(ùí™)={Œª‚Å¢(t)}Œª‚ààP‚à®. Therefore ‚Ñã‚Å¢(T‚Å¢(F),T‚Å¢(ùí™)) is the group algebra ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì‚Å¢[P‚à®] of P‚à®. The following result is called the Satake isomorphism.

Theorem 5.1.

The homomorphism ‚Ñã‚Üí‚Ñã‚Å¢(T‚Å¢(F),T‚Å¢(ùí™))=‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì‚Å¢[P‚à®] is injective and its image is equal to the subalgebra ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì‚Å¢[P‚à®]W of W‚Äìinvariants, where W is the Weyl group of G.

A crucial observation of R. Langlands was that ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì‚Å¢[P‚à®]W is nothing but the representation ring of the group GL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì), the Langlands dual group of G [L2]. By definition, GL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì) is the reductive group over ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì with a maximal torus TL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì) dual to T, so that its lattices of characters and cocharacters are those of T interchanged, and with the sets of roots and coroots being those of G, also interchanged (see [Sp]). For instance, the dual of G‚Å¢Ln is again G‚Å¢Ln, S‚Å¢Ln is dual to P‚Å¢G‚Å¢Ln, S‚Å¢O2‚Å¢n+1 is dual to S‚Å¢pn, and S‚Å¢O2‚Å¢n is self-dual.

Let Rep‚Å°GL be the Grothendieck ring of the category of finite-dimensional representations of GL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì). Then the character homomorphism Rep‚Å°GL‚Üí‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì‚Å¢[P‚à®] is injective and its image is equal to ‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì‚Å¢[P‚à®]W. Therefore Theorem¬†5.1 may be interpreted as saying that ‚Ñã‚âÉRep‚Å°GL. It follows then that the one-dimensional representations of ‚Ñã are nothing but the semi-simple conjugacy classes of GL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì). Indeed, if Œ≥ is a semi-simple conjugacy class in GL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì), then we attach to it a one-dimensional representation of ‚Ñã by the formula [V]‚Ü¶Tr‚Å°(Œ≥,V).

5.2. Towards the Langlands correspondence for an arbitrary reductive group

Now we can formulate for an arbitrary reductive group G an analogue of the compatibility statement in the Langlands conjecture Conjecture¬†2.2 for G‚Å¢Ln. Namely, suppose that œÄ=‚äóx‚àà|X|‚Ä≤œÄx is a cuspidal automorphic representation of G‚Å¢(ùî∏). For all but finitely many x‚àà|X| the representation œÄx of G‚Å¢(Fx) is unramified, i.e., the space of G‚Å¢(ùí™x)‚Äìinvariants in œÄx is non-zero. Then this space of G‚Å¢(ùí™x)‚Äìinvariants is one-dimensional and so ‚Ñãx acts on it via a character, which by Theorem¬†5.1 corresponds to a semi-simple conjugacy class Œ≥x in GL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì). Thus, we attach to an automorphic representation a collection {Œ≥x} of semi-simple conjugacy classes in GL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì) for almost all points of X. Therefore on the other side of the Langlands correspondence we need some sort of Galois data which would also give us such a collection of conjugacy classes.

The candidate that immediately comes to mind is a homomorphism

œÉ:GF‚ÜíGL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì),

which is almost everywhere unramified. Then we may attach to œÉ a collection of conjugacy classes {œÉ‚Å¢(Frx)} of GL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì) at almost all points of X. So in the first approximation we may formulate the Langlands correspondence for general reductive groups as a correspondence between automorphic representations of G‚Å¢(ùî∏) and Galois homomorphisms GF‚ÜíGL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì) which satisfies the following compatibility condition: if œÄ corresponds to œÉ, then the GL‚Äìconjugacy classes attached to œÄ through the action of the Hecke algebra are the same as the Frobenius GL‚Äìconjugacy classes attached to œÉ.

Unfortunately, the situation is not as clear-cut as in the case of G‚Å¢Ln because many of the results which facilitate the Langlands correspondence for G‚Å¢Ln are no longer true in general. For instance, it is not true that the collection of the Hecke conjugacy classes determines the automorphic representation uniquely or that the collection of the Frobenius conjugacy classes determines the Galois representation uniquely in general. Therefore even the statement of the Langlands conjecture becomes a much more subtle issue for a general reductive group. However, the main idea appears to be correct: there is a relationship, still very mysterious, alas, between automorphic representations of G‚Å¢(ùî∏) and homomorphisms from the Galois group GF to the Langlands dual group GL.

Now (in the hope of gaining some insight into this mystery) we would like to formulate a geometric analogue of this relationship. The first step is to develop a geometric version of the Satake isomorphism.

5.3. Categorification of the spherical Hecke algebra

Let us look at the isomorphism of Theorem¬†5.1 more closely. It is easy to see that the elements Œª‚Å¢(t), where Œª‚ààP+‚à®, the set of dominant weights (with respect to a Borel subgroup of GL), are representatives of the double cosets of G‚Å¢(F) with respect to G‚Å¢(ùí™). Therefore ‚Ñã has a basis {cŒª}Œª‚ààP+‚à®, where cŒª is the characteristic function of the double coset G‚Å¢(ùí™)‚Å¢Œª‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢G‚Å¢(ùí™)‚äÇG. On the other hand, Rep‚Å°GL also has a basis labeled by Œª‚ààP+‚à®, which consists of the classes [VŒª], where VŒª is the irreducible representation with highest weight Œª. However, under the Satake isomorphism these bases do not coincide. Instead, we have the following formula

(5.2) HŒª=q-(Œª,œÅ)‚Å¢(cŒª+‚àëŒº‚ààP+‚à®;Œº<ŒªaŒª‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢cŒº),aŒª‚Å¢Œº‚àà‚Ñ§+‚Å¢[q],

where HŒª is the image of [VŒª] in ‚Ñã under the Satake isomorphism. This formula has a remarkable geometric explanation.

Let us consider ‚Ñã as the algebra of functions on the quotient G‚Å¢(F)/G‚Å¢(ùí™) which are left invariant with respect to G‚Å¢(ùí™). In view of the Grothendieck fonctions-faisceaux dictionary discussed in Section¬†4.2, it is natural to ask whether G‚Å¢(F)/G‚Å¢(ùí™) is the set of ùîΩq‚Äìpoints of an algebraic variety, and if so, whether HŒª is the function corresponding to a perverse sheaf on this variety. It turns out that this is indeed the case.

The quotient G‚Å¢(F)/G‚Å¢(ùí™) is the set of points of an ind-scheme Gr over ùîΩq called the affine Grassmannian associated to G. Let ùí´G‚Å¢(ùí™) be the category of G‚Å¢(ùí™)‚Äìequivariant (pure) perverse sheaves on Gr. For each Œª‚ààP+‚à® we have a finite-dimensional G‚Å¢(ùí™)‚Äìorbit GrŒª=G‚Å¢(ùí™)‚ãÖŒª‚Å¢(t) in Gr. Let ICŒª be the irreducible perverse sheaf obtained by the Goresky-MacPherson extension from the constant sheaf on GrŒª to its closure Gr¬ØŒª. These are the irreducible objects of the category ùí´G‚Å¢(ùí™).

Assigning to a perverse sheaf its ‚Äútrace of Frobenius‚Äù function, we obtain an identification between the Grothendieck group of ùí´G‚Å¢(ùí™) and the algebra of G‚Å¢(ùí™)‚Äìinvariant functions on G‚Å¢(F)/G‚Å¢(ùí™), i.e., the spherical Hecke algebra. In that sense, ùí´G‚Å¢(ùí™) is a categorification of the Hecke algebra. A remarkable fact is that the function HŒª in formula (5.2) is equal to the function associated to the perverse sheaf ICŒª, up to a sign (-1)2‚Å¢(Œª,œÅ). Thus, under the Satake isomorphism the classes of irreducible representations of GL go not to functions which correspond to constant sheaves on the orbits (i.e., the functions cŒª) but to the irreducible perverse sheaves. This suggests that the Satake isomorphism itself may be elevated from the level of Grothendieck groups to the level of categories. This is indeed true.

In fact, it is possible to define the structure of tensor category on ùí´G‚Å¢(ùí™) with the tensor product given by a convolution functor corresponding to the convolution product (5.1) at the level of functions. Then up to a small subtlety, which has to do with the appearance of the sign (-1)2‚Å¢(Œª,œÅ) mentioned above, we have the following beautiful result. It has been conjectured by Drinfeld and proved by I. Mirkoviƒá and K. Vilonen [MV] and V. Ginzburg [Gi] (some important results in this direction were obtained earlier by G. Lusztig [Lu]).

Theorem 5.2.

The tensor category ùí´G‚Å¢(ùí™) is equivalent to the tensor category of finite-dimensional representations of the group GL‚Å¢(‚Ñö¬Ø‚Ñì).

Moreover, the fiber functor from ùí´G‚Å¢(ùí™) to the category of vector spaces (corresponding to the forgetful functor from the category of representations) is the global cohomology functor ‚Ñ±‚Ü¶‚äïiHi‚Å¢(Gr,‚Ñ±). This allows one to reconstruct the Langlands dual group GL by means of the standard Tannakian formalism. So we get a completely new perspective on the nature of the dual group. For example, the dual group to G‚Å¢Ln now appears as the group of automorphisms of the total cohomology space of the projectivization of its n‚Äìdimensional defining representation. This is a good illustration of why geometry is useful in the Langlands Program.

The above theorem should be viewed as a categorification of the Satake isomorphism of Theorem¬†5.1. We can use it to define the notion of a Hecke eigensheaf for an arbitrary reductive group and to formulate a geometric version of the Langlands correspondence. In the next section we do that for curves over ‚ÑÇ, but one can apply the same technique over the finite field as well.

6. The geometric Langlands conjecture over ‚ÑÇ

In this section we will formulate the geometric Langlands conjecture for an arbitrary reductive group over ‚ÑÇ. We will then give a brief overview of the recent work of A. Beilinson and V. Drinfeld in which a substantial part of this conjecture has been proved. It is interesting that their work uses results from representation theory of affine Kac-Moody algebras [FF, Fr], which now play the role of the reductive groups over local non-archimedian fields.

6.1. Hecke eigensheaves

In the rest of this paper X will be a smooth connected projective curve over ‚ÑÇ and G a reductive algebraic group over ‚ÑÇ. The results of Section¬†5.3 are applicable in this context. Namely, we have the affine Grassmannian over ‚ÑÇ and the category ùí´G‚Å¢(ùí™) of G‚Å¢(ùí™)‚Äìequivariant perverse sheaves (of ‚ÑÇ‚Äìvector spaces) on Gr. This category is equivalent, as a tensor category, to the category of finite-dimensional representations of the Langlands dual group GL‚Å¢(‚ÑÇ). Under this equivalence, the irreducible representation of GL with highest weight Œª‚ààP+‚à® corresponds to the irreducible perverse sheaf ICŒª.

Now we can define the analogues of the G‚Å¢Ln Hecke functors introduced in Section¬†4.3 for general reductive groups. Let BunG be the moduli stack of G‚Äìbundles on X. Consider the stack ‚Ñã‚Å¢e‚Å¢c‚Å¢k‚Å¢e which classifies quadruples (‚Ñ≥,‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤,x,Œ≤), where ‚Ñ≥ and ‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤ are G‚Äìbundles on X, x‚ààX, and Œ≤ is an isomorphism between the restrictions of ‚Ñ≥ and ‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤ to X\x. We have natural morphisms

‚Ñã‚Å¢e‚Å¢c‚Å¢k‚Å¢e‚Üôh‚Üê‚Üòh‚ÜíBunGX√óBunG

where h‚Üê‚Å¢(‚Ñ≥,‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤,x,Œ≤)=‚Ñ≥ and h‚Üí‚Å¢(‚Ñ≥,‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤,x,Œ≤)=(x,‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤).

Note that the fiber of ‚Ñã‚Å¢e‚Å¢c‚Å¢k‚Å¢e over (x,‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤) is the moduli space of pairs (‚Ñ≥,Œ≤), where ‚Ñ≥ is a G‚Äìbundles on X, and Œ≤:‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤|X\x‚Å¢‚Üí‚àº‚Å¢‚Ñ≥|X\x. It is known that this is a twist of Grx=G‚Å¢(Fx)/G‚Å¢(ùí™x) by the G‚Å¢(ùí™)x‚Äìtorsor ‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤‚Å¢(ùí™x) of sections of ‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤ over Spec‚Å°ùí™x:

(h‚Üí)-1‚Å¢(x,‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤)=‚Ñ≥‚Ä≤‚Å¢(ùí™x)‚Å¢√óG‚Å¢(ùí™x)‚Å¢Grx.

Therefore we have a stratification of each fiber, and hence of the entire ‚Ñã‚Å¢e‚Å¢c‚Å¢k‚Å¢e, by the substacks ‚Ñã‚Å¢e‚Å¢c‚Å¢k‚Å¢eŒª,Œª‚ààP+‚à®, which correspond to the G‚Å¢(ùí™)‚Äìorbits GrŒª in Gr. Consider the irreducible perverse sheaf on ‚Ñã‚Å¢e‚Å¢c‚Å¢k‚Å¢e, which is the Goresky-MacPherson extension of the constant sheaf on ‚Ñã‚Å¢e‚Å¢c‚Å¢k‚Å¢eŒª. Its restriction to each fiber is isomorphic to ICŒª, and by abuse of notation we will denote this entire sheaf also by ICŒª.

Define the Hecke functor HŒª from the derived category of perverse sheaves on BunG to the derived category of perverse sheaves on X√óBunG by the formula

HŒª(‚Ñ±)=h!‚Üí(h‚Üê(‚Ñ±)*‚äóICŒª).

Let E be a GL‚Äìlocal system on X. Then for each irreducible representation VŒª of GL we have a local system VŒªE=E‚Å¢√óùê∫‚Å¢VŒª.

Definition 6.1.

A perverse sheaf on BunG is a called a Hecke eigensheaf with eigenvalue E if we are given isomorphisms

HŒª‚Å°(‚Ñ±)‚âÉVŒªE‚ä†‚Ñ±,

which are compatible with the tensor product structure on the category of representations of GL.

In the case when G=G‚Å¢Ln this definition is equivalent to equations (4.2).

Now we can state the geometric Langlands conjecture.

Conjecture 1.

Let E be a GL‚Äìlocal system on X which cannot be reduced to a proper parabolic subgroup of GL. Then there exists a non-zero Hecke eigensheaf AutE on BunG with the eigenvalues E which is irreducible and perverse on each connected component of BunG.

When working over ‚ÑÇ, we may switch from perverse sheaves to ùíü‚Äìmodules. If V is a smooth variety, we consider the sheaf of differential operators on V and sheaves of modules over it, which we simply refer to as ùíü‚Äìmodules. The simplest example of a ùíü‚Äìmodule is the sheaf of sections of a vector bundle on V equipped with a flat connection (we can use the flat connection to act on sections by vector fields). The sheaf of horizontal sections of this bundle is then a locally constant sheaf, and hence a perverse sheaf. One can associate to a more general ùíü‚Äìmodule a perverse sheaf in a similar way. In fact, there is an equivalence between the category of holonomic ùíü‚Äìmodules with regular singularities on a variety V and the category of perverse sheaves on V, called the Riemann-Hilbert correspondence (see [B2, GM]). Therefore we may replace in the above conjecture perverse sheaves by ùíü‚Äìmodules. In what follows we will consider this ùíü‚Äìmodule version of the geometric Langlands conjecture.

6.2. The geometric Langlands correspondence as a Fourier-Mukai transform

Consider first the case of G=G‚Å¢L1. Then Bun1 is the Picard variety Pic and in order to prove the conjecture we should attach a Hecke eigensheaf AutE on Pic to each rank one local system E on X. Let œÉ:œÄ1‚Å¢(X)‚Üí‚ÑÇ√ó be the homomorphism corresponding to œÉ. It factors through the maximal abelian quotient of œÄ1‚Å¢(X), i.e., H1‚Å¢(X,‚Ñ§). But using the cup-product on H1‚Å¢(X,‚Ñ§) we may identify it with H1‚Å¢(X,‚Ñ§), which is equal to œÄ1‚Å¢(Pic0). Therefore œÉ gives rise to a homomorphism œÄ1‚Å¢(Pic0)‚Üí‚ÑÇ√ó and hence to a rank one local system on Pic0, or equivalently, a flat line bundle on Pic0. This flat line bundle (considered as a ùíü‚Äìmodule) is precisely the restriction of AutE to Pic0. It may be extended to the other components of Pic in the same way as in Section¬†4.4.

So in the case of G‚Å¢L1 the Hecke eigensheaves are actually flat line bundles. One constructs them by using the fact that rank one local systems on a curve X are the same as rank one local systems on its Jacobean Jac=Pic0. Note however that we have used the isomorphism H1‚Å¢(X,‚Ñ§)‚âÉH1‚Å¢(X,‚Ñ§). Because of that, if we take G to be an arbitrary torus T, then rank one local systems on connected components of BunT will correspond to TL‚Äìlocal systems on X.

One can strengthen the statement of the geometric Langlands conjecture by using the Fourier-Mukai transform. Let Loc1 be the moduli space of rank one local systems on X, or equivalently, on Jac. On the product Loc1√óJac we have the ‚Äúuniversal flat line bundle‚Äù Aut, whose restriction to {E}√óJac is the flat line bundle on Jac corresponding to E. It has a partial flat connection along Jac. This enables us to define functors between the derived category of ùí™‚Äìmodules on Loc1 and the derived category of ùíü‚Äìmodules on Bun1: pulling back to Loc1√óJac, tensoring with Aut and pushing forward to the other factor. It has been shown by G. Laumon [La4] and M. Rothstein [R] that these functors give rise to mutually inverse equivalences of derived categories, up to a sign. We note that a similar equivalence holds if one replaces Jac by an arbitrary abelian variety A, and it generalizes the original Fourier-Mukai correspondence in which one considers ùí™‚Äìmodules on A as opposed to ùíü‚Äìmodules.

Note that under this equivalence the skyscraper sheaf supported at the point {E}‚ààLoc1 goes to the sheaf AutE on Jac. So the above equivalence may be loosely interpreted as saying that any ùíü‚Äìmodule on Jac may be expressed as a ‚Äúdirect integral‚Äù of the Hecke eigensheaves AutE. In other words, the Fourier-Mukai equivalence may be viewed as a ‚Äúspectral decomposition‚Äù of the derived category of ùíü-modules on Jac.

Optimistically, one may hope that the Langlands correspondence for general reductive groups also gives a kind of spectral decomposition of the derived category of ùíü-modules on BunG (or, more precisely, its connected component). Namely, one may hope that there exists an equivalence between this derived category and the derived category of ùí™‚Äìmodules on the moduli stack LocGL of GL‚Äìlocal systems on X, so that the skyscraper sheaf on LocGL supported at the local system E corresponds to the Hecke eigensheaf AutE. If this is true, it would mean that Hecke eigensheaves provide a good ‚Äúbasis‚Äù in the category of ùíü‚Äìmodules on BunG, just as flat line bundles provide a good ‚Äúbasis‚Äù in the category of ùíü‚Äìmodules on Jac.

While it is not known whether this non-abelian Fourier-Mukai transform exists, A. Beilinson and V. Drinfeld have recently constructed a special case of this transform for an arbitrary semisimple group G. Roughly speaking, they construct ùíü‚Äìmodules on BunG corresponding to ùí™‚Äìmodules supported on a certain affine subvariety in LocGL called the space of GL‚Äìopers. Before discussing their construction, we consider its analogue in the abelian case.

6.3. A special case of Fourier-Mukai transform

The moduli space Loc1 of flat line bundles on X fibers over Jac=Pic0 with the fiber over ‚Ñí‚ààJac being the space of all (holomorphic) connections on ‚Ñí. This is an affine space over the space H0‚Å¢(X,Œ©) of holomorphic one-forms on X. In particular, the fiber over the trivial line bundle ùí™ is just the space H0‚Å¢(X,Œ©). As we have seen above, each point œâ‚ààH0‚Å¢(X,Œ©) gives rise to a flat line bundle on Jac. It turns out that we can describe the ùíü‚Äìmodule of sections of this flat line bundle quite explicitly.

Observe that because the tangent bundle to Jac is trivial, with the fiber isomorphic to H1‚Å¢(X,Œ©), the algebra D of global differential operators on Jac is commutative and is isomorphic to Sym‚Å°H1‚Å¢(X,ùí™)=Fun‚Å°H0‚Å¢(X,Œ©), by the Serre duality. Therefore each point œâ‚ààH0‚Å¢(X,Œ©) gives rise to a character œáœâ:D‚Üí‚ÑÇ. Define the ùíü‚Äìmodule ‚Ñ±œâ on Jac by the formula

(6.1) ‚Ñ±œâ=ùíü/Iœâ,

where ùíü is the sheaf of differential operators on Jac, and Iœâ is the left ideal in ùíü generated by the kernel of œáœâ in D. Then this is a holonomic ùíü‚Äìmodule which is equal to the Hecke eigensheaf corresponding to the trivial line bundle with connection d+œâ on X.

We note that the ùíü‚Äìmodule ‚Ñ±œâ represents the system of differential equations

(6.2) X‚ãÖŒ®=œáœâ‚Å¢(X)‚Å¢Œ®,X‚ààD,

in the sense that for any homomorphism from ‚Ñ±œâ to another ùíü‚Äìmodule ùí¶ the image of 1‚àà‚Ñ±œâ in ùí¶ is a solution of the system (6.2).

Generalizing the definition of the ùíü‚Äìmodule ‚Ñ±œâ we obtain a functor from the category of modules over Fun‚Å°H0‚Å¢(X,Œ©) to the category of ùíü‚Äìmodules on Jac,

(6.3) M‚Ü¶ùíü‚Å¢‚äóùê∑‚Å¢M,

so that œáœâ‚Ü¶‚Ñ±œâ. This functor is the restriction of the Fourier-Mukai functor to the category of ùí™‚Äìmodules on Loc1 supported on H0‚Å¢(X,Œ©)‚äÇLoc1.

Beilinson and Drinfeld have given a similar construction for an arbitrary semisimple group G.

6.4. Opers

Let G be a simple algebraic group, which we will assume to be connected and simply-connected in the rest of this section. Then the dual group GL is of adjoint type. The analogue of the affine space of connections on the trivial line bundle is the space of GL‚Äìopers.

Let G be a simple algebraic group of adjoint type, B a Borel subgroup and N=[B,B] its unipotent radical, with the corresponding Lie algebras ùî´‚äÇùîü‚äÇùî§. There is an open B‚Äìorbit ùêé‚äÇùî´‚üÇ/ùîü‚äÇùî§/ùîü, consisting of vectors which are stabilized by the radical N‚äÇB, and such that all of their negative simple root components, with respect to the adjoint action of H=B/N, are non-zero. This orbit may also be described as the B‚Äìorbit of the sum of the projections of simple root generators fi of any nilpotent subalgebra ùî´-, which is in generic position with ùîü, onto ùî§/ùîü. The torus H=B/N acts simply transitively on ùêé, so ùêé is an H‚Äìtorsor.

Suppose we are given a principal G‚Äìbundle ‚Ñ± on a smooth curve X with a connection ‚àá and a reduction ‚Ñ±B to the Borel subgroup B of G. Then we define the relative position of ‚àá and ‚Ñ±B (i.e., the failure of ‚àá to preserve ‚Ñ±B) as follows. Locally, choose any flat connection ‚àá‚Ä≤ on ‚Ñ± preserving ‚Ñ±B, and take the difference ‚àá-‚àá‚Ä≤. It is easy to show that the resulting local sections of (ùî§/ùîü)‚Ñ±B‚äóŒ© are independent of ‚àá‚Ä≤, and define a global (ùî§/ùîü)‚Ñ±B‚Äìvalued one-form on X, denoted by ‚àá/‚Ñ±B.

Definition 6.2.

A G‚Äìoper on X is by definition a triple (‚Ñ±,‚àá,‚Ñ±B), where ‚Ñ± is a principal G‚Äìbundle ‚Ñ± on X, ‚àá is a connection on ‚Ñ± and ‚Ñ±B is a B‚Äìreduction of ‚Ñ±, such that the one‚Äìform ‚àá/‚Ñ±B takes values in ùêé‚Ñ±B‚äÇ(ùî§/ùîü)‚Ñ±B.

This definition is due to Beilinson and Drinfeld [BD] (in the case when X is replaced by the punctured disc Spec‚Å°‚ÑÇ‚Å¢((t)) opers were introduced earlier by Drinfeld and Sokolov in their work on the generalized KdV hierarchies [DS]). Note that ùêé is ‚ÑÇ√ó‚Äìinvariant, so that ùêé‚Ñ±B is well-defined in (ùî§/ùîü)‚Ñ±B.

For instance, in the case when G=P‚Å¢G‚Å¢Ln this condition means that if we choose a local trivialization of ‚Ñ±B and a local coordinate t on X, then the connection operator will have the form

‚àá=‚àÇt+(***‚Ä¶*‚ãÜ**‚Ä¶*0‚ãÜ*‚Ä¶*‚ãÆ‚ã±‚ã±‚ã±‚ãÆ00‚Ä¶‚ãÜ*)

where the *‚Äôs indicate arbitrary functions in t and the ‚ãÜ‚Äôs indicate nowhere vanishing functions.

By changing the trivialization of ‚Ñ±B this operator may be brought in a unique way to the form

‚àÇt+(0v1v2‚ãØvn-1-100‚ãØ00-10‚ãØ0‚ãÆ‚ã±‚ã±‚ãØ‚ãÆ00‚ãØ-10).

But giving such an operator is the same as giving a scalar nth order scalar differential operator

(6.4) ‚àÇtn+v1‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢‚àÇtn-2+‚Ä¶+vn-1‚Å¢(t),

and a more careful calculation shows that it must act from Œ©-(n-1)/2 to Œ©(n+1)/2). So the space of P‚Å¢G‚Å¢Ln‚Äìopers is the space of operators of the form (6.4) (if n is even, we need to choose a square root of the canonical line bundle Œ©, but the space of P‚Å¢G‚Å¢Ln‚Äìopers is independent of this choice). In particular, it turns out that a P‚Å¢G‚Å¢L2‚Äìoper is nothing but a projective connection.

Lemma 6.3.

If G is a simple algebraic group of adjoint type and X is a smooth projective curve of genus not equal to one, then there exists a unique (up to isomorphism) G‚Äìbundle ‚Ñ±0 which admits the structure of an oper. Moreover, the corresponding Borel reduction ‚Ñ±0,B is also uniquely determined, and for any connection ‚àá on ‚Ñ±0 the triple (‚Ñ±0,‚àá,‚Ñ±0,B) is a G‚Äìoper.

For example, for G=P‚Å¢G‚Å¢Ln the bundle ‚Ñ±0 corresponds to the rank n vector bundle of (n-1)‚Äìjets of sections of the line bundle Œ©-(n-1)/2 (note that the corresponding P‚Å¢G‚Å¢Ln‚Äìbundle is independent of the choice of Œ©1/2).

Now we switch to the Langlands dual group. The above lemma means that the space OpGL‚Å°(X) of GL‚Äìopers on X is an affine space which is identified with the fiber of the natural projection LocGL‚ÜíBunGL over ‚Ñ±0.

Beilinson and Drinfeld associate to each point of OpGL‚Å°(X) a Hecke eigensheaf on BunG. Recall that in the abelian case the crucial point was that the algebra of global differential operators on Jac was isomorphic to Fun‚Å°H0‚Å¢(X,Œ©). Beilinson and Drinfeld prove an analogue of this statement in the non-abelian case. However, in this case it is necessary to consider the sheaf ùíü‚Ä≤ of differential operators acting on the square root of the canonical line bundle on BunG (this square root is unique up to isomorphism).

Theorem 6.4.

The algebra of global sections of the sheaf ùíü‚Ä≤ is commutative and is isomorphic to the algebra of functions on the space OpGL‚Å°(X) of GL‚Äìopers on X.

6.5. Hitchin‚Äôs integrable system

It is instructive to look at the quasi-classical analogue of this statement. The algebra D‚Ä≤=H0‚Å¢(BunG,ùíü‚Ä≤) carries the standard filtration by the order of the differential operator, and the associated graded algebra embeds into the algebra of functions on the cotangent bundle T*‚Å¢BunG to BunG. On the other hand, it is not difficult to show that OpGL‚Å°(X) is an affine space over the space

HG‚Å¢(X)=‚äïi=1‚ÑìH0‚Å¢(X,Œ©‚äó(di+1)),

where ‚Ñì is the rank of G, and the di‚Äôs are the exponents of G. Therefore the algebra Fun‚Å°OpGL‚Å°(X) carries a filtration such that the associated graded is Fun‚Å°HG. The quasi-classical analogue of the isomorphism of Theorem¬†6.4 is an isomorphism Fun‚Å°T*‚Å¢BunG‚âÉFun‚Å°HG.

To construct such an isomorphism, we need a morphism p:T*‚Å¢BunG‚ÜíHG. Such a morphism has been constructed by N. Hitchin [Hi]. Namely, let ùî§ be the Lie algebra of G. It is well-known that the algebra of invariant functions on ùî§* is isomorphic to the graded polynomial algebra ‚ÑÇ‚Å¢[P1,‚Ä¶,P‚Ñì], where deg‚Å°Pi=di+1. Let us observe that the tangent space to BunG at ‚Ñ≥‚ààBunG is isomorphic to H1‚Å¢(X,ùî§‚Ñ≥), where ùî§‚Ñ≥=‚Ñ≥‚Å¢√óùê∫‚Å¢ùî§. Hence the cotangent space at ‚Ñ≥ is isomorphic to H0‚Å¢(X,ùî§‚Ñ≥*‚äóŒ©) by the Serre duality.

By definition, the Hitchin map p takes (‚Ñ≥,Œ∑)‚ààT*‚Å¢BunG, where Œ∑‚ààH0‚Å¢(X,ùî§‚Ñ≥*‚äóŒ©) to (P1‚Å¢(Œ∑),‚Ä¶,P‚Ñì‚Å¢(Œ∑))‚ààHG. It has been proved in [Hi, Fa] that over an open dense subset of HG the morphism p is smooth and its fibers are proper. Therefore we obtain an isomorphism Fun‚Å°T*‚Å¢BunG‚âÉFun‚Å°HG. Moreover, for any œï,œà‚ààFun‚Å°HG, we have {p*‚Å¢œï,p*‚Å¢œà}=0, where {‚ãÖ,‚ãÖ} is the natural Poisson structure on T*‚Å¢BunG (so that p gives rise to an algebraic completely integrable system). This is a precursor of the commutativity property of the global differential operators.

6.6. Beilinson‚ÄìDrinfeld construction

How can we ‚Äúquantize‚Äù the map p, i.e., construct an algebra homomorphism Fun‚Å°OpGL‚Å°(X)‚ÜíD‚Ä≤?

In order to do this Beilinson and Drinfeld apply the following general construction. Suppose M~=Spec‚Å°B~ is an affine algebraic variety with an action of an algebraic group H. Let K be a connected subgroup of H and M=Spec‚Å°B another affine variety such that M=M~/K, so that B=B~K=B~ùî®, where ùî®=Lie‚Å°K. Set I=U‚Å¢ùî•‚ãÖùî®, where ùî•=Lie‚Å°H, and

N‚Å¢(I)={a‚ààU‚Å¢ùî•|I‚Å¢a‚äÇI}.

Then N‚Å¢(I)/I acts on B and hence we obtain a homomorphism N‚Å¢(I)/I‚ÜíH0‚Å¢(M,ùíüM).

The algebra N‚Å¢(I)/I may also be described as follows. Consider the induced ùî•‚Äìmodule V=Indùî®ùî•‚Å°‚ÑÇ. Then

N‚Å¢(I)/I=Vùî®=(Endùî•‚Å°V)opp.

In our case we let M be BunG. Let x be a point of X. In the case when the group G is semisimple, any G‚Äìbundle on X may be trivialized already on X\x and so one has the following stronger version of Lemma¬†3.1:

BunG‚âÉG‚Å¢(‚ÑÇ‚Å¢[X\x])\G‚Å¢(Fx)/G‚Å¢(ùí™x).

Let

Bun~G=G‚Å¢(‚ÑÇ‚Å¢[X\x])\G‚Å¢(Fx)

be the moduli space of pairs (‚Ñ≥,s), where ‚Ñ≥ is a G‚Äìbundle on X and s is its trivialization on the formal disc Dx=Spec‚Å°ùí™x. We may then set M~=Bun~G, H=G‚Å¢(Fx) and K=G‚Å¢(ùí™x). Though BunG is an algebraic stack, the above general construction is still applicable (see [BD]), and so we obtain a homomorphism

(Endùî§‚Å¢(Fx)‚Å°V)opp‚ÜíH0‚Å¢(BunG,ùíü).

Unfortunately, Endùî§‚Å¢(Fx)‚Å°V=‚ÑÇ, so we cannot obtain any non-trivial global differential operators on BunG. But the Lie algebra ùî§‚Å¢(Fx)‚âÉùî§‚Å¢((t)) has a one-dimensional universal central extension ùî§^Œ∫ called the affine Kac-Moody algebra:

0‚Üí‚ÑÇ‚Å¢K‚Üíùî§^Œ∫‚Üíùî§‚Å¢(Fx)‚Üí0

(see [Kac]). As a vector space it splits into a direct sum ùî§‚Å¢(Fx)‚äï‚ÑÇ‚Å¢K, and the commutation relations read

[A‚äóf,B‚äóg]=[A,B]‚äóf‚Å¢g-(Œ∫‚Å¢(A,B)‚Å¢Res‚Å°f‚Å¢d‚Å¢g)‚Å¢K,[K,‚ãÖ]=0.

where Œ∫ is a non-degenerate invariant inner product on ùî§ (which is unique up to a scalar).

Consider the ùî§^Œ∫‚Äìmodule VŒ∫=Indùî§‚Å¢(ùí™x)‚äï‚ÑÇ‚Å¢Kùî§^Œ∫‚Å°‚ÑÇ1, where ‚ÑÇ1 is the one-dimensional representation of ùî§‚Å¢(ùí™x)‚äï‚ÑÇ‚Å¢K on which ùî§‚Å¢(ùí™x) acts by 0 and K acts as the identity. Then one can generalize the above construction and obtain a homomorphism from

(Endùî§^Œ∫‚Å°VŒ∫)opp‚ÜíŒì‚Å¢(BunG,ùíüŒ∫),

where ùíüŒ∫ is the sheaf of twisted differential operators corresponding to Œ∫. In particular, if we choose the inner product Œ∫c defined by the formula

Œ∫c‚Å¢(A,B)=-12‚Å¢Trùî§‚Å°ad‚Å°A‚Å¢ad‚Å°B,

then ùíüŒ∫c=ùíü‚Ä≤, the sheaf of differential operators acting on the square root of the canonical line bundle on BunG.

The following result is due to B. Feigin and the author [FF, Fr].

Theorem 6.5.

If Œ∫‚â†Œ∫c, then Endùî§^Œ∫‚Å°VŒ∫=‚ÑÇ. If Œ∫=Œ∫c, then there is a canonical algebra isomorphism

Endùî§^Œ∫c‚Å°VŒ∫c‚âÉFun‚Å°OpGL‚Å°(Dx),

where Dx=Spec‚Å°ùí™x.

Thus, we obtain a homomorphism œÜx:Fun‚Å°OpGL‚Å°(Dx)‚ÜíD‚Ä≤, where D‚Ä≤ is the algebra of global differential operators acting on the square root œâ1/2 of the canonical line bundle on BunG. Beilinson and Drinfeld prove the following theorem [BD].

Theorem 6.6.

The homomorphism œÜx factors through a homomorphism

œÜ:Fun‚Å°OpGL‚Å°(X)‚ÜíD‚Ä≤

which is independent of x and is an algebra isomorphism.

This proves Theorem¬†6.4. Now, given a GL‚Äìoper œÅ=(‚Ñ±,‚àá,‚Ñ±B) on X, we construct a ùíü‚Äìmodule ŒîœÅ on BunG:

ŒîœÅ=(ùíü‚Ä≤/IœÅ)‚äóœâ-1/2,

where IœÅ is the left ideal in ùíü‚Ä≤ generated by the kernel of the character œáœÅ:D‚Ä≤‚Üí‚ÑÇ corresponding to the point œÅ‚ààSpec‚Å°D‚Ä≤ (compare with formula (6.1)). Since dim‚Å°OpGL‚Å°(X) =dim‚Å°BunG, the ùíü‚Äìmodule ŒîœÅ is holonomic (it is also non-zero). Denote by EœÅ the GL‚Äìlocal system (‚Ñ±,‚àá) underlying the GL‚Äìoper œÅ. Beilinson and Drinfeld prove the following fundamental result.

Theorem 6.7.

The ùíü‚Äìmodule ŒîœÅ is a Hecke eigensheaf with eigenvalue EœÅ.

Thus, Beilinson and Drinfeld prove the geometric Langlands Conjecture for those GL‚Äìlocal systems on X which admit the structure of an oper.

More generally, as in Section¬†6.3 we obtain a functor from the category of modules over the algebra Fun‚Å°OpGL‚Å°(X) to the category of ùíü‚Äìmodules on BunG:

M‚Ü¶(ùíü‚Ä≤‚Å¢‚äóD‚Ä≤‚Å¢M)‚äóœâ-1/2,

so that œáœÅ‚Ü¶ŒîœÅ. This functor may be viewed as the restriction of the would-be non-abelian Fourier-Mukai transform to the category of ùí™‚Äìmodules on LocGL supported on OpGL‚Å°(X)‚äÇLocGL.
